dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COUPLE moves down a walkway, deep in subdued conversati All around them trees explode with autumn color. Birds si Their path is dappled with leafy shadow. To their left, on the sunny meadow, TEENAGERS throw sauce and footballs, smoke cigarettes and joints, drink beer an soda, savoring the waning hours of summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is WILLS KEANE, late 40's to early 50's, strikingly  handsome, impeccably dressed, and supremely poised. At fi glance he has the proud glow of a hedonist who in the war against time has been the undisputed victor. Only a closer look hints at the toll of battle. His shoul strain under the weight of so much repetition. His eyes a touched by regret. The lines in his face reveal an emergi disenchantment not so much with the world as with himself Walking at his side is a WOMAN, 30, attractive and bright Her name is unimportant because so many have come before and, if the past prevails, so many will come after. She listens intently, as Wills finishes speaking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and I could have waited to tell  you, but I wanted to leave no room  for misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you certainly didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still talking quietly, they pass into a more secluded are of the park--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I see how you could feel this  way. Of course I do. It's human. But  what I don't get is why you'd want  to announce it so quickly. I mean,  we just met. Feelings change. You  don't even know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is amused by his confidence --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minute I laid eyes on you. It's  the saddest thing about getting older.  You know people so quickly. I even  knew you'd end up hating me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're wrong. I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a weary smile) Give it time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs. Then he stops. He hears something. She stops. She hears it, too. It's a GIRL'S VOICE. He casually turns and looks, squinting into the sun. He takes a few steps and there, between trees, he sees TW DOZEN PEOPLE sitting on the grass and on folding chairs - most are middle-aged or older with a distinctly intellect bohemian look to them. Standing and addressing them is CHARLOTTE FIELDING, 19, f willowy, pale, lovely in an unconventional way. She wears eccentric hat and a vintage dress. Her bearing is upright her gaze warm and intelligent, her voice rich with emotio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and for weeks I sat by her bed  and cried. I told her I loved her  and I begged her not to leave me.  All I could think about was what I'd  lose if she died. And then one  night... she was in really bad pain...  I stopped thinking about myself for  a second and I thought about her. (fighting tears) I stopped crying. I said goodbye.  And in less than an hour Ella was  gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman whispers in Wills' ear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Wills ignores her. He watches Charlotte with keen  interest, touched by the depth and sincerity of her emoti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really think it's possible to hold  a person back... cry them back...  from dying. That's what I did to  Ella and I'll never do it to anyone  else again. (softly) I hope no one ever does it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks out at the group, many of whom are crying. A te runs down her cheek. She smiles and wipes it away. The woman, seeing Wills' interest in the girl, whispers -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you know about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows a great deal. Or at least he thinks he does. But his answer is nonchalant --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That she's just a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the woman gently by the elbow and guides her awa He steals one last look back. Charlotte, returning to where she was sitting, notices Wi Their eyes meet and a charge passes between them. Meanwhile an OLD MAN has risen from his chair --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met Ella at City College in 1938...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills slowly turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SWARM OF PEDESTRIANS ascends the steps to the bustling  street. FIND CHARLOTTE amid the swarm, struggling with a load of  BOXES and SHOPPING BAGS, carrying an antique, wood-and-wi DRESSMAKER'S MANNEQUIN. She wears a peasant dress with a cycle jacket, a backpack and another eccentric hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte makes her way down the leaf-strewn pathway. Whe the mannequin by the neck, she passes NYU STUDENTS smokin laughing, and chatting on their way to class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte hauls the mannequin down the block. A YOUNG MAN offers her assistance, but she politely and firmly refuse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte wearily hauls the mannequin across the cobblest street, over the curb, and up to the stoop of a charming slightly dilapidated BROWNSTONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte opens the door into the darkness. She hits a li switch and nothing happens. She flips it back and forth -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dumps her boxes and bags, then wheels in the mannequi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly! The bulb burned out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EIGHT SILHOUETTES are crouched in the dark room. The mant is draped with a HAPPY BIRTHDAY BANNER. The coffee table stacked with WRAPPED GIFTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte looks suspiciously at the living room door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tiptoes through the darkness and lays her ear against it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear chuckles and whispers of anticipation. An older  woman's raspy, boozy voice growls --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ass hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few people chuckle, but they're quickly hushed. The DOO KNOB TURNS and the DOOR OPENS. Everyone leaps up in a bla of light --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SURPRISE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MANNEQUIN bursts into the room, teetering crazily, we CHARLOTTE'S JACKET, BACKPACK, and HAT. Everyone FLINCHES and SCREAMS. Amid a chorus of laughter, Charlotte enters. Grinning, she wags a facetious finger -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Surprises suck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An antique clock ticks crisply on the dresser. Wills stan before a mahogany mirror, buttoning a freshly laundered w shirt. Lying on the cradle bed, half-wrapped in a sheet, naked b for a string of pearls, is TANYA, 35, raven-haired, much thin. She smokes a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Wills, please, not again. It's  our third date and we're already in  a rut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought you loved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stretches with her cigarette but before she can make to the ashtray, her ASH FALLS on a New York magazine. On the cover is a PHOTOGRAPH OF WILLS standing next to a  YOUNG CHEF in a fashionable restaurant. The caption reads "The Prodigal Son Returns."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I do -- except for the fact that  there isn't a single thing on the  menu I can eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a chuckle) Sure, there is; there's just very  little you're willing to digest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips in a cuff link. She affects a breezy indifferenc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine then. We'll go, I'll get big,  fat, and horrible, and it'll serve  you right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills slips on a silk tie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it won't. Because it takes at  least a few weeks to get fat and by  then you won't even be speaking to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curiously) Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops tying his tie and stares at her in the mirror --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we have no future. All I can  offer you is this... what we have  right now... nothing more  meaningful... until it ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to tying his tie, then adds softly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have waited to tell you, but  I wanted to leave no room for  misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its decor is exquisitely tasteful, its ambiance warm and  convivial. The night is in full swing. Most of the tables are taken and the bar is packed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From amid the RUSH OF TRAFFIC, a TAXI breaks free and gli to the curb in front of the RESTAURANT. Its facade is windowless. Only a small brass plaque on th grey marble reveals that this is ELYSIUM. Wills and ERIKO, 30's, Japanese, aloof and stunning, emer from the taxi, elegantly dressed, and move to the front d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO TIPSY DEBUTANTES pass Wills and Eriko as they enter. recognizes Wills and smiles flirtatiously. Wills stops and helps Eriko off with her jacket. JESUS, 3 the dashing Cuban-American maitre d', superbly discreet,  approaches --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Keane. Will you be  dining with us tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We certainly will. Table seven, Jesus,  if it's available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills hands Eriko's jacket to MELISSA, 20, the hat check  girl --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Melissa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blushing) Fine, Mr. Keane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CELIA, mid-20's, the chipper, blonde Midwestern hostess,  arrives, wearing a stunned, glassy smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Celia. And how --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with forced cheeriness) Just dandy, sir, thanks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Table seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celia, barely making eye contact with Eriko, walks quickl away. Wills is amused and a little confused by Celia's  behavior. He lays a hand on Eriko's back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eriko nods and follows Celia. Wills moves to the reservation stand where his best frien and the restaurant's manager, JOHN VOLPE, 40, a brilliant dapper, tough as nails Brooklynite stands, listening to  someone on the telephone. Wills lays a hand on his shoulder and mutters into his ea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering the phone) Chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house specialty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy for you to say, ya prick.  Waltzin' in here like you own the  joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills laughs and takes a look into the bar. John gestures with his head in Eriko's direction --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who's the new potential ex-wife?  I thought you were still wastin'  time with Tanya-von-What's-her-name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wisely agreed to cut our losses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills exits into the bar. John smiles and shakes his head FOLLOW WILLS, as he glides along the bar. CUSTOMERS and S greet him warmly. As he enters the main dining room, DINERS spot him --  sprinkled among them are CELEBRITIES from every walk of c life. Wills greets them, stopping to shake their hands an kiss their cheeks. Suddenly, Celia, the hostess, red-faced, blocks his path

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I have no right to say this,  okay? And you can fire me if you  want, but in the six weeks we've  been open you've brought in six  different women -- tonight makes  seven -- and it's really starting to  get to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to greet them! It's like  working at a dog shelter! I'm afraid  to learn their names or even smile  at them because I know any minute  they could be put down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assure you it's an absolutely  painless procedure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shocked, she can't help but sputter a laugh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (beat) Especially for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both laugh. He moves closer, lowers his voice, and s with warm sincerity --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I appreciate your concern,  Celia. The truth is I'm a little  worried myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously. I've been trying to do  better. (uneasily) But... you know how it is... old  habits die hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm not fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. In fact, John's been looking  for an assistant. Tell him you've  just been promoted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills smiles, pats her in the shoulder, and moves on. She can't believe it. A WAITER carrying a BIRTHDAY CAKE -- blazing with candles and decorated with a WOMAN'S HAT made of MERINGUE LATTICE passes by on his way to the REAR DINING ROOM. From inside, VOICES begin to sing HAPPY BIRTHDAY. Wills, curiosity piqued, follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter sets down the cake at the center of a round ta There's a CHEER and APPLAUSE as the song ends. Wills cann see whose birthday it is because the waiter blocks his vi Just as Wills is about to exit the room, the waiter steps away. Wills glances over and sees the birthday girl. At f he can't place her, but then he does, and his face soften and brightens. It's Charlotte. She wears a black velvet dress and a  wonderfully eccentric hat. Her eyes glow in the candlelig Through the chorus of voices, urging her to make a wish, cries out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys! Let me think! (concentrating) Okay. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte blows hard, and, with a little more effort than you might expect, extinguishes the candles. Everyone APPL and CHEERS. To Charlotte's right sits SIMON LORING, late 20's, Englis sardonic, adoring. He gestures at her CHEST and says --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch carefully, everyone -- they  ought to begin emerging any moment  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs. Charlotte playfully slaps him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny! Actually, any moment now  you're gonna turn straight and fall  at my feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, darling, you know I would if I  could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte's best friend, SHANNON HARRIS, 19, a spoiled bu big-hearted redhead, drowning in curls, mutters --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only time he falls at your feet  now is when he wants to borrow your  Prada loafers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter. BACK TO WILLS. He considers approaching Charlotte, but th he looks back and sees Eriko sitting alone at their table idly stabbing at her drink with a straw. Regretting his rudeness, he takes a step toward her, but  then hears --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Wills Keane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and sees DOLORES TALBOT, 70, blonde wig, spindly frame, weathered skin, large, sad eyes. She holds a mixed drink --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure as hell is and he hasn't  changed a bit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, do I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little fool, it's Dolores Talbot.  Dolly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His smile shows uneasy surprise --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, time's kicked my ass  but good. Come on, Romeo, let's bury  the hatchet. Give me a hug. Careful  of the cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he hugs Dolores, he can't help but look over at Charlo again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what the hell're you doin' around  here? Last I heard you were out in  earthquake country blowin' the family  fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I doubled it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON CHARLOTTE. She looks over. Her view is such that she s Wills but not Dolores. A faint blush creeps into Charlotte's cheeks. She pretend to listen as Shannon tells a story --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and you know how bouncer's get.  He's like, "That's the worst fake  I.D. I've ever seen." And I'm like,  "Yeah? Well, you have the worst dread- extensions!" And then just when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noticing Charlotte's distraction, Simon whispers calmly t her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you feeling all right? You look  positively green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte speaks under her breath without moving her lips

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here. And he's staring at me  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Shannon and Simon turn to look, but like lightning  Charlotte grabs them both --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't! (to Simon) Wait a few seconds, then go to the  bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will I know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's beautiful. And much older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? (getting up) If he's rich you might have a fight  on your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte watches furtively as Simon rises from his chair and walks over. As he passes Wills, he flashes him a sedu smile. Wills is confused by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shannon swivels her head and throws an aloof, vacant star in Wills' direction. Then she looks back at Charlotte, mo agape --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's as old as my dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte laughs. BACK ON WILLS. He does his best to be attentive as Dolore exhales a plume of smoke into his face --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, L.A.'s okay if you're a cactus  or a lizard, but if you're a New  Englander, your soul dries up and  blows away like a god damn leaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It only took me twenty years to come  to my senses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what're you doin' now? You owned  some restaurants out there, didn't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON CHARLOTTE. She sits listening to Shannon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, after all that, we pay our  cover, we get in, and it's totally  heinous! Nothing but losers and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte looks over and pales, her eyes widening --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores walks up, hauling Wills by the arm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids! I want you to meet an old chum  of mine, the owner of this fine  establishment -- Wills Keane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table greets him. Wills, slightly self-conscious, loo at everyone but Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that over there's the birthday  girl -- my granddaughter, Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news hits Wills hard. But he does his best to hide it He musters a casual smile --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Katie and Jay's daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet. She got her height from her  dad. But her talent's all Katie's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores indicates the hat that Charlotte's wearing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made it herself from scratch. That  one, too. (to Shannon) Honey, show 'im.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shannon makes an elaborate comic show of modeling the hat she's wearing. The table laughs. Wills levels his gaze at Charlotte --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try as she might to accept the compliment with grace,  Charlotte can't help but grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WINE STEWARD stands at a station on which sit TWO BOT OF CHAMPAGNE on ice. He reaches for one. Wills stops him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we can do better than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steward, understanding, nods and departs, taking the  champagne with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Twenty years old and never been...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amused, he flashes Charlotte his most dazzling smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let you get back to your  celebration. (kissing Dolly's cheek) A pleasure to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills turns to exit. Simon, returning to his seat, murmur seductively to Wills as he passes by --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving so soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills looks at him, confused again, then continues on. As Simon sits, he mutters to Charlotte --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be still my beating heart. (beat) Or is that your heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper to Charlotte) You're not really into him, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte turns to Dolores who has just sat down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dolly, how do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uneasily) From Newport. Old friend of your  mom's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores eats a sloppy forkful of birthday cake.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: A gentle breeze tickles a white lace curtain. A PHONE RIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte, standing in the small antiquated kitchen, wear flannel pajamas, tenses when she hears the PHONE RINGING  UPSTAIRS. She snatches an apple from a bowl and dashes ou of the room. FOLLOW CHARLOTTE running through the DINING ROOM... into LIVING ROOM... into the FOYER... and up a DARK STAIRCASE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A startling clash of childhood, adolescence, and womanhoo Everything from stuffed animals to posters of pop icons t volumes of great literature.

dialogues.speaker: THE PHONE RINGS AGAIN
dialogues.text: Charlotte bangs in, flings herself on the bed, and grabs phone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, bitch, I'm ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills sits in his woolen robe, holding a portable phone.  Amused, he smiles into the morning sun --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I'm so sorry! Wait. Who  is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills Keane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her heart stops. She sits up slowly, her body tensed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did you think it was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend Simon, actually. He always  calls me the morning after to sort  of... you know... sum everything up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how would you sum it up,  Charlotte? Turning twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda cool, kinda creepy. Anyway,  you wanna speak to my grandmother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a chuckle) I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVIA, 30's, Wills' Jamaican cook and housekeeper, enter Plump, handsome, and perpetually amused, she carries a tr laden with continental breakfast and a New York Times. Wi mouths a greeting. She smiles back and sets the tray on a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called because I'm going to be  attending a benefit... a black-and- white ball.... and I'd like you to  design a hat... for my date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Wow. Sounds fun. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a gift. I don't have her  measurements, but she's about your  size. What're you, a six?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good -- then let's assume your hat  size is also the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that doesn't necessarily --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a risk we'll just have to take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte runs over to her sewing table, looking for a pe and paper. She finds paper, but no pen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her dress is a sheath... sleeveless,  black. The hat must, of course, be  black or white or both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds a pen but it doesn't work. She grabs an eyeline and uses that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any particular style?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sipping his coffee) No, just plenty of it. How long will  it take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have till Thursday. I'll need it  here by seven o'clock. I'm at the  Pembroke on Central Park West and  76th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Wow. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your fee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faltering) I don't really have one. I usually  just make them for friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's five hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His tone has abruptly shifted; it's intimately hushed. It both daunts and excites her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say "wow" a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to stop. You're a woman now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She clicks off the phone, wilts into a swoon on the bed, breaks out laughing. Wills, still holding the receiver, stares dreamily into t middle distance. He snaps to when Olivia enters. Her accent is as much Que as it is Caribbean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, now you got me worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You slept alone last night. You must  be sick or somethin'. You want me to  call a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, no, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws him a sly, sidelong glance, then exits. Wills  laughs and contentedly sips his coffee. FROM THE NEXT SCENE, we hear the sound of SQUEALING, LAUG SHOUTING CHILDREN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by swarming PARENTS and KIDS, Wills stands wit John, the manager of Elysium, and his wife, SARAH VOLPE, who, gazing out of frame, keeps a watchful eye on their k

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save it, pal! Don't even bother! I  may not have gone to a fancy school  like Bendover --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) That would be Andover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, if his folks could have afforded  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but when Wills Keane comps three  bottles of Dom to a twenty-year-old  girl, then tells me he did it 'cause  he likes the kid's grandma, I smell  a rat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) Oh, is that what that is? I figured  there was a dirty diaper somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly) Okay, I admit it, she interests me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Sarah) He's gonna do it! I don't believe  it! He moved us back here for nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So much for that turned leaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Come on, you're overreacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you think? Buddy, since  we hit town, I have done nothin' but  cut you slack! Every week a new woman  on your arm and I didn't say a word.  Why? 'Cause I figured at least they're  in the right demographic. Maybe by  accident you'll trip over something  substantial. But this little girl?  Best she could be is Miss Right's  daughter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uneasily) I know. It's just that there's  something about her. She's special...  and I just thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "She's young. She's hot. I'm on the  verge of menopause. Why not go for  it?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills and Sarah meet eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wouldn't be much point in lying  to you, would there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy, Daddy, look, look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY and CARLA, the Volpes' five-year-old TWIN DAUGHTERS run up, beaming, each carrying a huge stuffed animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, they're bigger than you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John scoops both his daughters up in his arms and kisses  them repeatedly. Wills watches, his eyes filling with a vague, wistful env He sees Sarah staring at him. She smiles sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The furniture is antique and dark. The white walls are ti with yellow from years of cigarettes. In one corner, the  paint has chipped off the ceiling in a jagged plate. Dolores sits on a worn-out leather arm chair, smoking, si a cocktail, watching a DAYTIME TALK SHOW. In the background, we see Charlotte working in the ADJOIN DINING ROOM which she has turned into a lovely sewing roo CLOSER ON CHARLOTTE. She builds her hat on a HAT BLOCK -- wooden mannequin head. Strewn all around her are the mate of her hatmaking -- bolts of cloth, hat blocks, a sewing  table. Shannon, wearing sweats and a T-shirt, lies on the floor, eating M+M's and drinking diet soda, while heavily markin up a text book with a YELLOW HIGHLIGHTER. Charlotte stops and rubs her eyes, then she glances down Shannon and smiles --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you mark what isn't  important? That way you'll save ink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you sew your mouth to my  butt? That way you'll stop annoying  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both laugh. Overhearing, Dolores croaks facetiously

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, if you two kids can't play  nice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shannon rolls over onto her back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I hate school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte pins a strip of black lace to the hat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, just last week, you  said you were on a roll. You loved  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now I'm on the rag and I hate  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte chuckles and sets the half-finished hat on her  head. Still seated, she wheels her work chair over to a m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're incredibly lucky. I'd  love to be going to college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shannon rolls over and looks at her. Suddenly her express is inexplicably solemn --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I the most spoiled brat in the  world or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spoiled brats don't even ask questions  like that. (re: the hat) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She models the hat. Tears well in Shannon's eyes and she  says without even a hint of irony or sentimentality --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you're the most beautiful person  in the entire world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte smiles, looks away, and, trying not to cry, fus with the hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold autumn rain falls. The Irish doorman, MICHAEL, 60' melancholy, stoop-shouldered, smokes a cigarette, looking at the unburdening sky. A LIMOUSINE pulls up. The passenger window glides down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey! How ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit early, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, in this soup, better safe than  sorry, you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUNNING FOOTSTEPS approach. Michael looks. The driver loo too. It's Charlotte, dressed in tattered jeans, a light rain c and sneakers, dashing at breakneck speed down the street, carrying something in a GARBAGE BAG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEANE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs right past Michael --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael works the shiny brass controls. Charlotte, winded hair dripping wet, watches the numbers tick by overhead.  Michael smiles at her with paternal fondness --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's goin' to a fancy party tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte, nonplused by his lack of discretion, smiles  politely --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your step, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She emerges, moves to Wills' door, and waits for the elev to close. When it does, she hurries back to a table over  which hangs a GILDED MIRROR. She takes a LOVELY OLD HAT BOX out of the garbage bag and ditches the bag under the table. Then she quickly checks  herself in the glass. She doesn't like what she sees. She pokes at her sopping  hair and squeezes it, but it's hopeless. Remembering the  time, she hurries back to the door, takes a deep breath, rings the bell. She waits. And waits. Then she hears footsteps approachin She realizes she's left the hat box on the table. She rushes over and grabs it, just in time to get back to the door when it OPENS. Olivia, the housekeeper, steps out, wearing her coat and  carrying her purse. Her voice is low and gentle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's waitin' for you, Miss Fieldin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange cordial smiles. Charlotte enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte steps into a dim hallway lined with oil paintin carpeted with a Persian runner, and lighted by three anti sconces. She walks slowly, terribly self-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is vast, furnished with antiques, decorated with the same masculine good taste. Charlotte enters timidly,  then hears --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks and sees Wills standing, back turned, before a  broad set of high windows. City lights glimmer in the  distance; beneath them lies the vast gloom of Central Par

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't get a cab, so I took the  subway... only it was an express and  it didn't stop at --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You realize, don't you, that you're  a full eighteen minutes late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... I'm so sorry... I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills turns around. A magnificent figure -- expertly tail tux, every hair in place, freshly manicured. And then he  offers her an amused, reassuring smile --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte, relax. What's the point  of being a beautiful young woman if  it isn't to keep your admirers  waiting? In fact, you disappoint me:  I was looking forward to at least  another half hour of suspense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flattered, her face brightens --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could leave and come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, too late. Anyway, I want to  see the hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over to her. Smiling, she sets down the box, unt the ribbon, and gingerly removes the hat. It's sublimely  simple and elegant. She looks at him with hope. His face  betrays nothing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I'm soaked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte, a little confused, carefully sets the hat on h head. She steps to a wall mirror, pulls the veil down, an sets it at the correct angle. Wills appears behind her and shares the reflection. She f his presence, hears his breathing. They speak in hushed t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's perfect. It's like a tiny  sculpture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted it to be a tiny poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles. Their eyes meet in the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only I had some use for it. (off her look) My date canceled a few hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. She was vague. Would  you... like to come in her place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte can't believe it. She smiles at his reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outfit I bought her is hanging  in the guest room closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxiously) It's okay? Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures toward the half-open door on other side of th room. Charlotte turns and, biting her lip, looks at the d then back at Wills, then back at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spectacular affair is in full swing, a benefit for the  METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART attended by FIVE HUNDRED GUEST from HIGH SOCIETY dressed only in black and white. A LARGE BAND plays -- everything from waltzes to jazz to  swing. Chandeliers glisten. Guests, sitting in ornate box look down on the marble dance floor where a WALTZ is in  progress. FIND WILLS AND CHARLOTTE, dancing together. Charlotte loo sophisticated and beautiful beyond measure, wearing a  sleeveless black sheath with a fake fur wrap, and, of cou her hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You're very good. Where  did you learn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Ella. The woman whose memorial  you crashed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you did see me there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. And the next time I saw you,  you were on the cover of New York  magazine. And I had to pick a place  for my birthday. So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a few beats for Wills to put it together. He smi realizing that her presence at Elysium wasn't a coinciden She smiles back, sweetly, coyly. ON THE PERIMETER, FIND TWO RICH WOMEN, 40's, too thin, to lifted, watching Wills and Charlotte waltz. They stand with LISA, 23, unassuming, fair-haired, simply dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he moved back. I mean,  he'd already seduced every A- and B- list actress in town. What was left  for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Lisa looks at her, feigning naivety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The C-list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if what I hear is true and he's  shopping for a bride, I can tell you  one thing -- he's barking up the  wrong tree there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an icy smile) Good wives are rarely found up cherry  trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women share a laugh. Lisa, slightly discomposed, look back at Wills and Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills and Charlotte slow dance to a romantic ballad. Will seems entranced by her easy manner of expression --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met Ella in the fourth grade. She  was my teacher at the Little Red  School House. We stayed friends after  she retired. She taught me how to  cook and sew... speak Italian...  basically enjoy life, have fun --  that's what she was best at... even  when she knew she was dying. (pause) The most important thing she did was  introduce me to poetry. She believed  it was the highest form of art and  that everything we say and do should  aspire to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills is uncomfortable for a moment, then ventures quietl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds as though, in a way, she  took your mom's place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom and my dad's. After they died,  Dolly was so devastated she pretty  much gave up on everything. It was  like if something that tragic could  happen, there was no way she was  ever gonna care about anyone else  ever again. Including herself. She  wasn't a horrible parent... she didn't  abuse me or anything... she just  ignored me. She was more like a weird  landlady than a grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte smiles sadly. Her eyes glisten in the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she did the best she could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a long time I kinda thought that,  too, and I made excuses for her, but  now I don't. I was seven years old  and I needed her and she wasn't there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence as Wills somberly reflects. Finally, he speaks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember when I heard the news  about your parents. You know how  after a crash they print a long list  of names in the newspaper? Well, I  grew up outside Boston, so I naturally  started to scan the list. But  casually, not expecting to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, a SWING SONG starts. Wills smiles at the ironic change of mood, then turns to escort Charlotte away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, come on! I love this stuff!  Don't you? Didn't you grow up on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ancient!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding his hand, she starts moving to the music. Wills l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea what to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have fun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flings her wrap onto a chair and keeps dancing. Wills charmed senseless, finally surrenders. A SEQUENCE BEGINS during which we see WILLS and CHARLOTTE having an inordinately good time. Wills maintains a modic of reserve; Charlotte is joyful and entirely unembarrasse CERTAIN GUESTS NOTICE THEM. The reactions to their pairin runs from confusion to disgust to amusement. But no one watches them more carefully than Lisa. Finally, in the middle of a song, Wills and Charlotte mak their way off the floor, winded and laughing. Wills heads off to the bar. Charlotte turns around and watches the ot dancers. Then we notice Lisa standing next to her. They smile at e other. Lisa offers her a cocktail napkin. Charlotte takes and wipes off her brow. They speak above the music --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to come. I work at the Met.  What's your excuse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Wills Keane, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just by reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A major womanizer, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they say. (beat) I'm Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte Fielding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands. Lisa looks away and sees Wills making h way toward them with two glasses of punch. Coolly covering, Lisa beats a hasty retreat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I should keep mingling. But  it was nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa smiles politely and walks away. Wills walks up, watching Lisa melt into the crowd. His br is furrowed. He's wondering if his eyes have deceived him He hands Charlotte a punch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name hits home. Wills is flustered, but then he cover as best he can and lifts his glass --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting his glass) Here's to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills smiles slowly and they toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is empty. There's laughter in the distance. The  front door opens and shuts. We hear Wills and Charlotte,  both a little tipsy, advancing down the hall toward us --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you talk like you're a hundred  and sixteen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's usually how I feel. But not  tonight. Tonight I feel sixteen...  just sixteen... and three-quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills crosses to the bar and from a small refrigerator pu out a BOTTLE OF CHAMPAGNE already sitting in an ice bucke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Champagne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked nonchalantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills laughs, then opens the bottle as he picks up his  previous train of thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Charlotte, the way you know  you're getting older is that you  start to notice patterns. People  start falling into types. Pretty  soon you know a person before you've  even been introduced. And if it's a  woman, before the romance even starts,  a whisper in your head tells you  exactly what it is and how long it's  going to last. And the saddest, the  most tedious, part of all is that  that little voice is almost always  right. (popping the cork) Now, what I like about you -- and I  think that's actually what inspired  this little lecture -- is that I  find you completely unprecedented...  and, therefore, wholly unpredictable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it must be a relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To finally deliver that speech to a  woman and actually have it apply to  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, because coincidentally I am all  those things you just said. And more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills chuckles, shaking his head, charmed but a little  unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a "unique". At least that's what  my yoga teacher says. He says there  are very few uniques in the world  and I'm one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's a wise man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her a glass of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, on the other hand, are what  he'd call a "typical."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. And I can prove it. Want me  to? Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills moves a few steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills walks even closer, until they are just a few feet a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, come on, really close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills can't believe his good luck. He nears her until the faces are almost touching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect. Now watch very carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises on tiptoe and puts her mouth just inches from h Their breathing mingles. Wills seems almost dizzied by it And then, very slowly, he kisses her. She does not kiss back. Finally, he pulls away, staring blankly, breathing hard, sure what to say. Charlotte whispers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? You're a typical. (pause) And for what you just did, most girls  my age would slap your face. Or ask  to be put in a cab. (pause) Lucky for you, I'm a unique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, then kisses him deeply on the mouth. Her arms wrap around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cloaked in deep shadow, set off against a rainy window pa we see Wills, his shirt off, on top of Charlotte whose bl is open. He passionately kisses her neck and mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is bathed in golden light. Charlotte lies naked  under the covers asleep on her stomach. Her brow is tense and one of her hands is slightly clenched. ANGLE ON WILLS, standing in the doorway, watching her, hi face a portrait of conflicted thoughts. Finally, she stirs. Smiling and squinting into the sun, s gets up on one arm and looks at him, standing there in th doorway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, do you look guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte happily wolfs down her continental breakfast. W sits across from her, watching and worrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't anyone ever teach you that  it's bad manners to stare at a girl  when she's eating like a pig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills chuckles, then his smile fades and he clears his th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Here it comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, because, look, I could  put this off, but I genuinely like  you. So I want to be clear... right  now... from the start, so there's no  chance for misunderstanding later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I want to say you is.... well...  that all I can offer you is this...  what we have right now... nothing  more substantial... just this...  until it ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him. Lowers her fork. He adds almost relucta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is, we have no future  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills' face reddens slightly. He shifts uneasily in his c A suggestion of a smile plays along his features --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What... what do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I said. Nobody thought I'd even  last this long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills stares at her blankly, not knowing what to think or say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have put off telling you,  but I genuinely like you, so I wanted  to be clear... you know, right from  the start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olivia enters, takes her orange juice glass and leaves a  full one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Olivia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte gulps down the juice. Wills watches, his mind  reeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills sits across from a large desk, beneath a wall of fr certificates and diplomas. The door opens and DR. PAUL SI 60, African-American, dour and forbidding, enters --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Keane? Dr. Sibley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills jerks to his feet and they shake hands --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for taking the  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my job, sir. Please, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks around the desk. Sibley is all business, but his brusqueness masks genuine regret --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. Keane, on the phone you  referred to Charlotte's condition as  cancer. That isn't strictly accurate.  Neuroblastoma is a soft tissue  malignancy, but it isn't cancer --  although it sometimes can be just as  aggressive. (sitting) It's most common in children. In  young adults, the condition is  extremely rare. In Charlotte's case,  the tumor is located in her chest.  It's growing rapidly and has proved  resistant to both irradiation and  chemotherapy. And because of its  proximity to her aorta, surgery is  out of the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then what treatment is she getting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At present? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills shifts uneasily in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually she'll be treated for  pain. In the end, surgery could become  an option, but her chances of survival  would be slim. Right now Charlotte's  against it. She's signed a directive  forbidding any sort of heroic  intervention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence settles between them. Sibley opens a folder on desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more here if you're  interested, but it won't mean much  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills shakes his head and rises from his chair. He turns the door, then turns back to the doctor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Optimistically? A year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing her tattered jeans from the night before, Charlot sits on the couch doing the New York Times crossword. Wil emerges, walking slowly, pensively, as though in a trance Charlotte looks up and masks her anxiety with a grin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real charmer, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills doesn't react. He keeps walking toward her. Unsettl she holds up the puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you on Cambodian money units?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills keeps advancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay, old man? You look kinda  woozy. (jokingly calling out) Is there a doctor in the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignoring her, Wills sits down, takes her in his arms, and embraces her. At first she resists, but slowly she surren and hugs him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cab bounces down a cobblestone Village street, Wil and Charlotte stare straight ahead, each following the  tortuous path of his own thoughts. Slowly, Charlotte steals a sidelong look at him. His face tense, ashen, and unreadable --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills slowly turns his head. She smiles sweetly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look on the bright side: if I weren't  sick, there's no way we could hang  out together. (off his look) I'm serious. You'd be scared of  hurting me and I'd be scared you  were just using me for my perfect  young body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't help but smile. Encouraged, she moves closer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then our friends would say we  were just into each other for weird  psychological reasons. You know,  because I'm looking for a daddy  substitute and you're looking for  someone you can feel superior to so  you won't have to confront how scared  you are of real intimacy -- and, of  course, they'd be right and eventually  we'd break up. (beat) But since I'm so sick it doesn't  really matter what deep-seated  weirdness has brought us together  because there's no way we can possibly  screw each other over... or up...  because that takes time. And I don't  have much left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab comes to a stop in front of her brownstone. She s archly, savoring the irony --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So considering everything, don't you  think we should just sort of chill  out, forget I'm sick, and enjoy what  we have... right now... no strings...  just this... until it ends? 'Cause  that's really all I have to offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills grimly appreciates the irony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it, okay? But not too  hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses his cheek and jumps out of the cab. She skips the steps of the brownstone, then immediately turns aroun and runs back down to the open window. She leans in and mutters sexily --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night was so incredibly hot. (beat) By the way -- it was my first time.  And I picked you for the job. I hope  you're flattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills is shocked. She turns and runs back upstairs. She s in the key, then turns and waves at Wills before banging  open the door with her hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, pal, where to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills hasn't moved a muscle. FROM THE NEXT SCENE, we hear the pop of FLASHBULBS and th whirr of SHUTTERS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG FASHION MODELS OF EVERY RACE strut down a runway,  modeling a new line of WOMEN'S URBAN CASUAL WEAR. FIND CHARLOTTE, ignoring the show, pushing through the cr hurrying toward the side of the stage. She speaks to a GU at the entrance and he lets her pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte searches amid the chaos of models dressing and  undressing. Finally, she spots them. FIND SIMON AND SHANNON styling a BLACK FEMALE MODEL in a  tank top and fatigues. He applies a finishing touch, adjusting the tilt of the  model's baseball cap. Shannon, lacing the girl's boots, w as Simon's assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The threesome, in high spirits, bangs open a fire door.  Shannon is beside herself, frantically half-screaming --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it! I don't believe  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what Miss Harris is trying  to say, is that you've strained her  credulity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Better put some ice on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shannon lifts a hand to high-five her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girlfriend, you are so incredibly  cool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I've been told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon high-fives her instead. The girls laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now tell us everything! Don't  leave anything out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM THE NEXT SCENE, we hear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant is empty. John stands behind the bar, taki an inventory of the liquor. In the background, TWO BUSSER mop up. Wills sits on a bar stool, nursing a mineral wate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. I took her home and she  pointed out an irony -- that fate  was now offering us the very same  thing that just this morning I'd  told her was all I could offer her:  a relationship with no future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) A kid figured that out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not a kid! That's what I've  been trying to tell you. Nothing's  lost on her. I'm the kid. She... I  don't know what the hell she is... (muttering) But I do know what she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John looks at him curiously. Wills glances over his shoul at the bussers, then leans in close --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A virgin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The busboys turn their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea. That's the only reason  she had her party here, so she could  lure me into doing the honors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) She used you, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hangman got hanged. How's it  feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John laughs. Wills settles into a brooding silence. John  goes back to work --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I end it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you're endorsing this now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, continuing his work, smiles sweetly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, when you talk about  her, you're not such an arrogant son  of a bitch. You get all whiny and  stupid. I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And since I don't see you gettin'  serious with any of your other  victims, I figure why not spend a  little time together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got bad news for you, brother, so  are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills stares at him thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills stands stiffly at the door, holding a bouquet of  flowers. He stares at his own reflection in the porthole  window. He straightens his hair, tugs at the collar of hi cashmere jacket. Footsteps approach. The door opens and there's Dolores, b eyed and disheveled. She smiles sourly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the dark prism of Dolores' inhospitable wariness, catch glimpses of the high-society hostess she once was -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be right down. She's upstairs,  gildin' the lily. (shouting up the stairs) HE'S HERE! (wryly) Do come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move through a doorway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills is surprised by the room's run-down state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse the mess. My maid died fourteen  years ago and it's been simply  impossible to replace her. She did  windows and spoke English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She chuckles to herself. Wills hands her the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, aren't they loverly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She casually drops them into an EMPTY BLENDER at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Care for a cocktail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon lounges on the bed. Charlotte stands before a full- length mirror, trying on a dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really is uncanny. I tell you, in  that dress you're the spitting image  of Michel Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flattered) Who's she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A French character actor, long dead,  who was not only hideous and fat,  but quite male.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that would be a "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon nods. Charlotte takes off the dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills looks around the room. Dolores splashes her drink w vodka --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I say? Time's a thief. One  day you're rich as an Arab, the next  you're lucky if you can afford a god  damn can of pistachio nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills wanders over to the mantel where FAMILY PHOTOS sit tarnished antique silver frames. He picks up a photograph a YOUNG GIRL in TENNIS WHITES -- it's Charlotte's mother, Katie. Wills' face is suffused with tenderness as he studies it. Dolores walks over and looks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about that, huh? That was the  summer you two --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd have guessed what time had in  store for her, huh? Look at that  smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes moistening, Dolores crosses to her armchair. Her ton is slightly bitter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then again, time loves some people.  Like you, for instance. Oh, time's  just wild about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She plops down unsteadily and reaches for her cigarettes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as handsome and charming as  ever. And still up to the same old  tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills sets the photo back on the mantel --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time you came to pick up Katie,  you brought me flowers. Just like  those. (to herself) Flower the mother; then deflower the  daughter. But Katie was too smart  for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolly, look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly) Aw, why the hell don't you leave her  alone? Christ, she's sick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before Wills can answer, they hear footsteps on the  stairs. Neither moves. Charlotte enters, wearing a peasant dress and felt hat,  looking pretty, pale, and excited. Wills and Dolores slowly turn. They smile at her, then  exchange a quick glance. Charlotte catches it and becomes self-conscious --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like your mom is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte looks to Wills to see if that's, indeed, what h was thinking. He nods his agreement. She is pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte, full of energy, hauls Wills down the block by hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you knew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did! I just didn't think it would  take so long!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days is long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is when you're sitting by the  phone. You wanna know how I knew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're psychic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, but no -- it's because of my  birthday wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we hadn't even been introduced  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but I wished that whatever  happened... you know, with my  illness... I'd go out with a bang.  Nothing heavy. No violins. No  melodrama. Just fun. A total  adventure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte jumps off the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAREFUL!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He yanks her back just as a TAXI, horn blaring, SPEEDS PA nearly hitting her. For a moment, they both stand there, hearts pounding,  breathing hard. Then Charlotte looks back at him and grin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, it's getting exciting already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a perfect blue sky, the park swarms with autumn  celebrants. Charlotte and Wills move together down a walk Half-joyously and half comically, Charlotte addresses the heavens with grand theatricality --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Lord, I do fear  Thou'st made the world too beautiful  this year!  My soul is all but out of me, -- let  fall  No burning leaf; prithee, let no  bird call!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could go to a museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that would be a thing! I don't  want to do any thing today. I want  to do no thing all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. No thing at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So a movie is out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice cream at the Plaza? High tea at  the Palace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about shopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She considers for a few moments --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only when I have money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sidewalk swarms with pedestrians. Wills and Charlotte emerge empty-handed from the revolving door of a departme store --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all I gave you was champagne.  That's not a proper birthday present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree, and I promise I'll let you  give me something else, but not today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon. But I'm warning you, it's not  going to be anything material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? (then solemnly) Oh, I see... because you're sick.  Because --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, but we're not gonna  talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's my rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any particular reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, because everybody always wants  to talk about miracles, or about  some genius quack-doctor, or their  friend's friend who went into  remission eating nothing but sunflower  seeds. It's boring and pointless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I mean, there are  specialists who --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start, okay? (abruptly) Now what I would enjoy is taking you  shopping. For clothes. I'm serious.  It's quality not quantity, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills sits in a chair while Charlotte looks through silk  scarves --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At work you should look perfect, but  in everyday life you need to delight  in disorder more. Don't you know? "A  sweet disorder in the dress kindles  in clothes a wantonness."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that goes without saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was true when that poem was written  three hundred years ago and it's  true today. Wouldn't it be fun to  look wanton occasionally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a lifelong dream of mine.  But will a scarf do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally. Accessories rule. But we  have to be careful. I don't want you  looking too young. Nothing's worse  than an old guy trying to look young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good advice. I'll remember that for  when I get old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I'm old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills walks a little self-consciously. He wears around hi shoulders a sloppily draped wrinkly silk scarf. He walks past OTHER SHOPPERS. Among a GROUP OF WOMEN walk past him FIND CHARLOTTE who subtly checks him out as thou he were a stranger. As she passes by, she gives him a sexy look, then, not ve subtly, she spins around to look at his ass. Finally, she breaks character, runs after him, and throws her arms around his neck from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly imperfect!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughing, he holds her hands and hauls her on his back to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills and Charlotte are in the middle of a candlelight di Wills refills her wine glass --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why, but for some odd  reason, I feel absolutely compelled  to tell you the truth about this...  even at the risk of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're giving me the creeps.  Just spit it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills holds his breath for a moment, then exhales and say it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had a date for the benefit.  My plan from the beginning was for  you to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte sets down her wine glass as she pieces it toget

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I made the hat for myself? (He nods.) And you bought that dress for me? (He nods.) And you did all this just so you  could sleep with me? (He nods.) Why? I mean, why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills settles himself, then, meeting her eyes, speaks sof

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eulogy you gave at Ella's service  was so... impressive. You spoke about  her death... about loss... in a way  that I could never have done. You  understood life emotionally in a way  that I didn't. Whatever that  understanding was, I wanted to get  close to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sex seemed like the best way to  do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the most enjoyable, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlotte sips her wine and considers. Then she sets down her glass --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, first of all, let me say, you  have great taste because that little  Dolce & Gabbana was to die for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, second, don't ever lie to me  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously. There isn't a lie in the  whole world I'd rather hear than the  truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills stares at her solemnly. Her expression just as somb she lifts a hand and points to her lips. He leans forward kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wills and Charlotte, kissing deeply, tumble fully clothed onto the bed. As their passion builds, Wills reaches for bedside lamp. Charlotte watches curiously, thoughtfully, as he pulls th cord, plunging the room into UTTER DARKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC UP
dialogues.text: -- Savoring the last sunny days of autumn, Wills and Char walk across the green of Central Park, which swarms with  happy, healthy teenagers. -- At night, Wills and John and his wife Sarah sit in box seats at Yankee Stadium watching the play-offs. Bernie  Williams hits a colossal shot. The crowd jumps to its fee As the ball flies over the right field wall, we see that  Charlotte sits next to Wills, munching a hotdog, her nose buried in a book, utterly uninterested. -- In Elysium's kitchen, Wills watches on as Charlotte,  wearing an apron over her clothes, prepares bisque under approving eye of the CHEF. She quickly and expertly pours cup of cream and a cup of broth into a large blender. The she dumps in lobster meat and adds some saffron. Just whe she, with a dramatic flourish, is about to hit the start  button, Wills INTERRUPTS and puts the lid on the blender. -- One morning, Charlotte sits up in bed doing the Sunday New York Times crossword puzzle. Olivia sits on the chair next to the bed, chatting and laughing with her. Wills en carrying a silver tray laden with breakfast. Olivia looks and gestures haughtily for him to set it down, as though were the housekeeper. -- At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Wills and Charlotte wander amid the shadows of Egyptian ruins. MUSIC OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
